div.head: A Prodigious, and moÅ¿t lamentable accident, Lately befallen the Citie of PLEVRS, Belonging to the Signiorie of VENICE: Which happened in the beginning of September laÅ¿t paÅ¿t, 1618.
div.p: SUch is the prauitie of our nature, that wee alwayes rather feele the Å¿mart of Gods Diuine vengeance falling vpon vs, than weigh the counÅ¿els and purpoÅ¿e of his heart, which hee aymeth at in the midÅ¿t of his wrath, puniÅ¿hing and correcting vs for our juÅ¿t deÅ¿erts, by which wee haue couÅ¿trained him to turne his mercy into juÅ¿tice, and fauour and benefits, into rods and Å¿courges.

The effects whereof falling out daily before our
eyes, in this behalfe, tende to none other ende, but to rowze vs out of that lethargie of Å¿in into which wee bee fallen, and to let out the Å¿welling of our pride: that at the length wee may carefullie aduiÅ¿e our Å¿elues, before our finall deÅ¿olation fall vpon our heads. But (alas) wee are Å¿o hood-winked, and Å¿enÅ¿eleÅ¿Å¿e, in the middeÅ¿t of this our miÅ¿erie, that for want of a diÅ¿cerning eye, wee are readie to attribute all miÅ¿Å¿e-happe to Å¿econdarie cauÅ¿es, and to extraordinarie effectes: rather than wiÅ¿elie to bethinke vs, in judging, that the roote from whence all our euils Å¿pring, is from our Å¿elues.

From none other cauÅ¿e proceedeth all the caÅ¿ualities which happen euerie day in our Å¿ight: but eÅ¿peciallie of late yeares, as well by the laÅ¿t effectes of Fire, Aire, and Water, as by other vnawonted accidentes, proceeding from the elementes, which God vÅ¿eth as his roddes to afflict man withall.

Wee know, that within a yeare, or there abouts, what hath hapned both in France, and elÅ¿ewhere, to the great aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment of mortall men, who are but duÅ¿t and aÅ¿hes, and whereat indeed the greateÅ¿t wits haue Å¿tood amazed.
Spaine was at her wittes ende, in admiring that Deluge which befell in the Earledome of Barcellonne, with much ruine and loÅ¿Å¿e in this verie moneth and time of the yeare.

France it Å¿elfe hath had no cauÅ¿e to mocke at her Neighboures harmes, but to bee vvhollie taken vp vvith feare, hauing Å¿eene, the Lenton laÅ¿t paÅ¿t, 1618. the vvonderfull burning and conÅ¿umption of the Pallace of her head Citie; the Sanctuarie of the Innocent, the terrour of the guiltie, where the Oracles of Trueth were euerie daye to bee hearde, by vncorrupt ARISTIDES, inflexible in the cauÅ¿e of Equitie, and a juÅ¿t conÅ¿eruer of Right and ReaÅ¿on.

But all this is but a little, in reÅ¿pect of that, which as wee heare, hapned vpon the Countreyes belonging to the Signiorie of VENICE, in the beginning of this preÅ¿ent moneth of September, to the ruine and vtter loÅ¿Å¿e of the Towne, or Citie, of PLEVRS: namelie, that about that time, the fourth, or the fifth, of this preÅ¿ent moneth, happened vpon the Territories of the Å¿aide Cittie Å¿uch a fearfull and prodigious Å¿torme, mingled with thundring and lightnings, with winde and tempeÅ¿t, that it Å¿eemed Heauen and Earth woulde haue gone together, and that the laÅ¿t times, fore-tolde by Daniel, were nowe inflicted there: and that which is worthy of greateÅ¿t wonder and aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment, was an exceeding vehement winde, encloÅ¿ed and Å¿hutte vppe within the bowels & hollowneÅ¿Å¿e of the earth, with certaine fires burning vnder the grounde, vvhich vvith their violent encountering each of other,
with blaÅ¿ts, & counter-blaÅ¿ts, made Å¿uch an hideous noyÅ¿e within thoÅ¿e holes and narrow places, wherewith the Countrey was filled, that it cauÅ¿ed a verie Å¿trange Å¿haking, or trembling, of the Earth: yea, Å¿o fearfull, that the effects enÅ¿uing thereof are incredible: Thence came the totall and deplorable loÅ¿Å¿e of the Å¿aid Citie of PLEVRS, Å¿omewhat greater, and better peopled, than is S. Denis in France. For the Earth opening it Å¿elfe, by the vehemencie of theÅ¿e fires vnder the ground, and the bluÅ¿teringes of theÅ¿e winds incloÅ¿ed within her bowels, and in Å¿eeking vent, that in this opening and trembling of the earth, the Å¿aid City was wholly Å¿unken and Å¿wallowed vp, with all and euery one of the houÅ¿es and buildings, with the loÅ¿Å¿e of moe than two thouÅ¿ande Å¿oules, crauing for mercy in Å¿o great, Å¿o Å¿udden, and vnexÅ¿pected a calamity. And within the Å¿aid Territorie, many Trees, Woods, & ForreÅ¿ts, were Å¿ome of them ouerthrowne by the windes, and otherÅ¿ome were conÅ¿umed and burnt, aÅ¿well by the fire of heauen, as by the flames iÅ¿Å¿uing foorth, and vomited from out of the bowels of the earth: VVhich Å¿trucke Å¿uch an aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment into the neighbour Countreyes, that all fell to prayers, made publicke and Å¿olemne proceÅ¿sions: taking it for a certain forewarning of Gods mercy turned into fury, and for a Å¿ure vndoubted token, that his anger is kindled againÅ¿t the Å¿onnes of men: Å¿eeking hereby to appeaÅ¿e him in the midÅ¿t of his juÅ¿t conceiued diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure.

div.p:
THE effects of Nature are of Å¿o deepe comprehenÅ¿ion, as the moÅ¿t Å¿ubtill PhiloÅ¿ophers haue loÅ¿t themÅ¿elues in the admiration thereof. The flowing and ebbe of an Eurypus made him loÅ¿e all his reaÅ¿on, who laboured to Å¿ettle the principles and groundes therof: And he who Å¿o Å¿earched into the courÅ¿e and originall of it, returned from thence aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed with wonder, and beÅ¿otted with ignorance. In briefe, her Å¿ecrets are Å¿o darke and hidden, as mortall eyes can
make no diÅ¿couerie thereof: God, the Author of Nature, reÅ¿eruing, as a particular to himÅ¿elfe, the knowledge of thoÅ¿e myÅ¿teries, with a barre to all others to enter into them. And if man can challenge to himÅ¿elfe any little taÅ¿te thereof, he hath it by purchaÅ¿e from that great diÅ¿tributer of knowledge, and with the price of paines and trauels innumerable.

The accident which happened in freÅ¿h memorie, about a moneth Å¿ince, in a certaine Towne called Pleurs, Å¿ubject to the State of the GriÅ¿ons, a people confining with the Territorie of Millaine, and with Switzer-land, cannot but beget in vs both aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment and admiration together: aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment, for the Å¿trangeneÅ¿Å¿e: admiration, in that we are not able to comprehend the cauÅ¿e and ground thereof. This is not the fable of remouing mountaines, & heaping one vpon the top of another by Ouids gyants, to Å¿cale Heauen withal: but a true fact, which as it made the Earth to tremble, Å¿o may it doe the heartes of the moÅ¿t couragious men, and make them Å¿hake, by Å¿haking things, to all mens thought, immooueable: Å¿o as nowe wee can grounde no firme aÅ¿Å¿urance vpon Rockes, and Chaunge reigneth by courÅ¿e ouer all thinges. This Towne of Pleurs, aboue named, Å¿eated vpon the land, and amongÅ¿t the people of the GriÅ¿ons, is Å¿ubject for the Temporalities, vnto the Lordes of that State: and for the Spiritualities, in as much as it is whollie PopiÅ¿h, (excepting onelie
three or foure houÅ¿es,) it is vnder the juriÅ¿diction of the BiÅ¿hop of Como. It is rich, well peopled, famous for Trade, the Kirkes (well recommended for their building, rich Ornamentes, and TreaÅ¿ure,) Å¿eeme Å¿ufficientlie to witneÅ¿Å¿e the pietie of that people. One of them was conÅ¿ecrate vnder the name of Sainct Iohn of Silan: and the other, more renowned than that, by the name of Sainct CaÅ¿sian.

The particulars as well of this Countrey, as of this Towne, which are not indeede of our diÅ¿courÅ¿e, cannot but bee tedious to the Reader, who attendeth with impatience the newes of a caÅ¿e Å¿o Å¿trange as this is. This Towne is in a Valley, vnder the mountaine Chrouena, in neare neighbourhood, and not aboue the diÅ¿tance of two leagues from the confines of Millaine: and of like neareneÅ¿Å¿e to the Porte of Tuentes; Å¿tanding vpon the banke of the Lake of Como, where paÅ¿Å¿eth the Riuer of Mora: which Riuer, although it carrie a Å¿trong and violent current, yet can it not, in anie reaÅ¿on, be preÅ¿umed to haue beene the cauÅ¿e of this ruine vvhereof vvee are to Å¿peake. Nature had fortified this Towne, and immured it, as it were, betwixt two mountains: the one whereof was Å¿ingularlie fertile in Winter, and other Fruites of the Earth making her appeare with another couÌ„tenance, than of an hideous Rock: which could promiÅ¿e no pleaÅ¿ure nor delight, but of Å¿uch an Hill as Å¿upplyed the Inhabitantes with infinite commodities, vnder-ground Caues, & Gardens,
Store-houÅ¿es; and other commodious places, which they found within the boÅ¿ome of this mountaine, with all Å¿orts of pleaÅ¿ures, delightes, and delicates. This other Hill, which is aboue Silano, and beyond the Riuer, is Å¿omewhat more diÅ¿tant from the Town, which, it Å¿eemeth, Nature had purpoÅ¿ely remooued from the Å¿ame, leÅ¿t it might (perhaps) too much Å¿hadow and obÅ¿cure it, that the great multitude of trees wherewith this Hill was repleniÅ¿hed, being of it Å¿elfe higher and Å¿teeper than the former, and yet bearing (notwithÅ¿tanding the Å¿teepeneÅ¿Å¿e) both hay and wood, for the Å¿upply of this Towne. CloÅ¿e to this mountaine there Å¿tood another, much higher than the Å¿ame, and wholly barrend and deÅ¿arted: a fatall Hill, and deÅ¿tined to the ruine of this miÅ¿erable Towne, and all her inhabitants.

The fourth day of this inÅ¿tant month of September, this great and Å¿teepe Hill was Å¿haken, either by Å¿ome windes vnder the ground, or by Å¿ome Å¿ecret tempeÅ¿t which Nature raiÅ¿ed from within her bowels: in Å¿uch fort, as about Å¿ix a clock in the euening, that which Å¿eemed to be vnmoueable, was Å¿eene in a Å¿hort Å¿pace to be pulled vp by the roots, and borne away by the fury of the windes. A Å¿trange caÅ¿e, there neuer hauing beene Å¿eene Å¿o great and fearfull an Earth-quake. This mountaine then being Å¿haken with his fury, fell with Å¿uch violence vpon that vnhappy Towne, as it buried both it, and all the inhabitants together. It was about Supper-time, at
what time the moÅ¿t parte of the Townesmen were Å¿et at Table, when they found themÅ¿elues ouerwhelmed with theÅ¿e Å¿o mightie ruines, vnder which, at an inÅ¿tant they gaue vppe the ghoÅ¿t. Scarcelie was any man exempted, for of three thouÅ¿and & Å¿ix hundreth perÅ¿ons, which at that time were reckoned to bee in the Towne, there eÅ¿caped onelie foure, of whome wee will Å¿peake more particularlie heereafter. The loÅ¿Å¿e of goods was exceeding great, inaÅ¿much as the eÅ¿teemate thereof paÅ¿Å¿eth three Millions of Golde. The rage and tempeÅ¿tuous force of the windes was Å¿o outragious, as they that were in the fieldes felt themÅ¿elues thereby transported into places whollie vnknowne. The Lord Laurence Scandolera reporteth, that being in a Garden of his, with his Niece, hee was borne by the violence of that tempeÅ¿t aboue and beyonde the Riuer: and hee was found on a little Hill, called Ronco, hauing a Napkin at his Shoulder, and his Legges broken off. The people comming a little to themÅ¿elues, ran to beholde this Å¿pectacle, vvhere in Å¿tead of finding a Towne, in the Valleye before mentioned, they
found an high and fearfull mountaine, hauing within its entralls Å¿wallowed the whole company of its poore inhabitants: no man eÅ¿caping, Å¿aue only four, as were Å¿aide, whom wee will name in particular, to giue more aÅ¿Å¿urance to the trueth of the fact.

The Riuer Mora, which watered all this Valley, hath thereby loÅ¿t its naturall and ordinary current: and hath beene enforced to recouer its courÅ¿e more than a league from the place. This is the Å¿umme of what happened in the places afore Å¿aid, being in trueth a wonder vnmatchable in any Age.

The Deeps below, and Fire aboue, hold Å¿ome extraordinary power of Nature: but to Å¿ee mountains remoue, and change their places, wee muÅ¿t in trueth auouch, that this thing is Å¿o high, and the cauÅ¿es Å¿o hidden, as humane wit cannot pierce into the depth of theÅ¿e profound myÅ¿teries. To make Nature Å¿o
potent, as to giue occaÅ¿ion for the vvorld to thinke, that this accident proceeded from the force of the winds, which perhaps were Å¿hut vp within the womb of the Earth, and there had intermixed with Å¿ome encloÅ¿ed fire, which hauing vndermined this mountaine, did in Å¿uch Å¿ort ouerturne it, were to attribute vnto Nature too much force and Å¿trength. To call to remembrance another Sodome, wherof this is the image, the colours only excepted, I meane the forme of their deÅ¿truction: to aÅ¿cribe this calamitie to the judgement of God, were to partake with the Å¿ecrets of the HigheÅ¿t, and as companions to his Throne, to giue Å¿entence againÅ¿t his people.
